dialogues.text: A perfectly-restored Ford pick-up with some vintage objec in the bed drives slowly along a street lined with modest gracious two-storey houses. ELLA’S AND JOHN’S HOUSE - DAY 2 Will enters through the kitchen door without knocking. He puts down the bags and announces his presence with forced good cheer:

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Mom? It’s me! You ready? Jane’ll be here any minute. I made a cake for Dad, hazelnut and carrot. No butter or sugar, so you can have a slice! No answer. Will starts to explore various rooms.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where are you guys? It’s a cozy, slightly messy house. There’s a living room a fireplace, a big library. Will collects an open book an shelves it, then folds a shirt that’s been tossed on a ch He opens the door to the master bedroom. The bed is unmad His father John’s study. The roller desk is piled high wi books and papers. There’s a big old desktop computer righ the middle of it all.  Scene 2 Page 2. On the shelves of a large bookcase that is cluttered with essays and books, there’s an old Remington typewriter Joh used to work with, its beautiful keyboard like a sculptur Will emerges from the front door onto the porch, turning the phone in frustration. He scratches his head. An elder lady in gardening attire stands in the yard next door. It LILLIAN, the neighbor. She’s gray-haired, friendly:

dialogues.speaker: LILLIAN
dialogues.text: Will! How are you?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (approaches her) Hey, Lillian.

dialogues.speaker: LILLIAN
dialogues.text: (whispers) I’m glad I caught you alone. I wanted to tell you that if you guys get busy with Ella in the hospital, I'd be more than happy look in on John.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: But they’re not here! Mom and Dad - the house is empty! He redials. Lillian gives him a curious look.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (grumbles ) Why’d we even buy her that damned phone? She always turns it off.

dialogues.speaker: LILLIAN
dialogues.text: Come to think of it, I heard someone turning on an engine this morning. Very early.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What motor? Dad's car’s right here. He points to a perfectly-maintained old Chevy in the open garage. And then he realizes the large covered carport is open.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh my god! He’s white as a ghost. He runs toward the carport. Lillia also shocked. She murmurs:  Scene 2 Page 3.

dialogues.speaker: LILLIAN
dialogues.text: I can’t believe this. Will frantically dials and impatiently awaits an answer:

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Jane! Mom and Dad are gone! And - can you believe it? - so is the Leisure Seeker!

dialogues.text: And here they are: ELLA and JOHN. He’s got a white beard wears glasses with progressive lenses. He looks like he’s totally absorbed in his driving. Every so often he shoots look at Ella, who uses her gaze to encourage and direct h which way to go, while also keeping an eye on a map sprea her lap. She has a small, golden purse on her knee, from which she occasionally pulls a tiny mirror to check her appearance.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Take a right. Here. Exactly. Very good. John follows orders with a mysterious calm. Ella watches closely.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Couldn’t you have worn something more comfortable to travel in? He’s wearing a checkered shirt under a tweed jacket. A li handkerchief protrudes from his breast pocket. She leans closer and sniffs.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I think you've exaggerated a bit with the eau de cologne. Though you do smell nice.  Scene 4 Page 4. John smiles agreeably, but something tells us that he’s n really grasping what he’s being told. He sniffs the air a the camper’s interior fills now with the sound of: THE RONETTES SINGING ‘BE MY BABY’ He finally speaks:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Darling? Eyes on the road, he waits until he has her attention.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (with pleasure) You did!

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello! Hi! Such beautiful children... you can go now, hon. The street’s clear. John? Go! Put that old engine to work!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yessir.  Scene 4 Page 5. John accelerates, turning right onto an on-ramp for the interstate. A red gasoline light goes on, accompanied by

dialogues.speaker: ELLA

dialogues.text: We need gas? Ella checks the gauge and then glances at the map on her

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Our Stuckey’s, hon. Come on, try to remember.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Is the store closed? We really wanted one of your delicious Pecan Logs.

dialogues.text: (accent) Opening soon. Just gas now.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: No, I can’t believe it. You hearing this, hon? John nods, imperceptibly, although he doesn’t seem much interested. So Ella makes friends with the attendant.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Every summer we’d head south, and we always stopped at Stuckey’s. Jane and Will - the kids - they’d make us stock up on Pecan Logs.

dialogues.speaker: MALE ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Yes, I see.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: We were visiting my family in South Carolina. That’s where I’m from. John, on the other hand, he’s a real Yankee. Born and bred.

dialogues.speaker: MALE ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Ah, okay. He exchanges a puzzled look with the Female Attendant, wh after finishing the windshield, walks away grinning.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: They were lovely trips. Right, John? I guess I’m just a natural born tourist. I love to travel. Smoky Mountains, Six Flags, Williamsburg... you ever been to any of those places?

dialogues.speaker: MALE ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: We are from Syria.  Scene 5 Page 7.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Well, they’re amazing. You should take the family. Do you have children? The man’s face darkens momentarily with sadness. But he overcomes it.

dialogues.speaker: MALE ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: That’1ll be ninety-one dollars, ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Certainly. She pulls money from her purse and leans out the window t hand it to him. As she does, she quietly confides:

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: John is a much more sophisticated tourist than me. Oh, he likes to travel, but he thinks travel should broaden the intellectual horizons, whatever that’s supposed to mean... The attendant pockets the money and gives her a curt nod.

dialogues.speaker: MALE ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Have a very nice journey.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Thank you, and I’m sorry if I spoke too much. I do love to chitchat. (to John) Let’s roll, hon! John does as he’s told, putting the camper in gear, but a soon as they start to move the Female Attendant waves the a stop. There’s something in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Oh, you'd have to ask John about all that. Though he’s taking a nap right now. The FEMALE CAMPER appears.

dialogues.speaker: MALE CAMPER
dialogues.text: Look at this old beauty, babe. So have you folks been on the road long?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Actually, we just started. We’re headed south, down to where I grew up, between Charleston and Savannah.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CAMPER
dialogues.text: It’s so beautiful there!

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Yeah, we'd always go on vacation there. But this time we’re going even further south. All the way down to the Florida Keys.

dialogues.speaker: MALE CAMPER
dialogues.text: Wow!

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I’m finally taking John to Hemingway's house in Key West - have you ever been? They both shake their heads.

dialogues.speaker: MALE CAMPER
dialogues.text: Now, Hemingway was a Confederate general, right?

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CAMPER
dialogues.text: No, silly, he was a writer. Didn't he commit suicide?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Yes. I never understood why...  Scene 14 Page 21. Ella's voice trails off. For a moment, she seems deeply m and lost in thought, as if she’s only now beginning to understand why. But then she snaps out of it.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: John knows everything about him. He’s always wanted to see that house. Every year I’d promise him we'd go, but, you know how it is travelling with little kids... of course we've been to Melville's place. That’s just a few hours from our house. Have you been there? He wrote Moby Dick. It’s very interesting. Her neighbors nod, not knowing what to make of all this.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .». it was actually a big pain in the rear for me and Will (she laughs). My daughter loved it. I think that’s why she became a professor. John is so proud of her. He’s a teacher too. The neighbors continue to smile, though now they exchange look, wondering how to escape this talkative lady.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Poor Will, on the other hand, he’s still struggling to find his way... The Male Camper pats his pockets, looking desperately at wife - time to go - but then John appears at the door of Leisure Seeker, looking groggy, his hair out of place.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Where are we? We’re not home.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: No, honey. We live in Massachusetts. This is Pennsylvania.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What the dickens are we doing in Pennsylvania?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: We're on vacation. And we're having a whale of a time, right?  Scene 14 Page 22.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Not me. I want a cup of tea. He sits next to Ella, who smiles bravely at the neighbors

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: My husband John. And these are our neighbors...?

dialogues.speaker: MALE CAMPER
dialogues.text: Bob Taylor. And this is my wife Janette. Hate to say it, but...

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CAMPER
dialogues.text: -..-it’s a little late...

dialogues.speaker: MALE CAMPER
dialogues.text: ...uhm, yeah, we need to put the kids to sleep... They flee. MALE CAMPER (CONT’D) Maybe catch you later...

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CAMPER
dialogues.text: Yes, maybe...

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I hope so! (hisses to John) Just Say goodbye...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I want a cup of tea. Ella smiles at the neighbors, as if to apologize. After t close the door, she turns to John in irritation.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I’1ll make your tea when I’m good and ready. I’m quite comfortable sitting here.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: But I want it now.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: You'll just be up peeing all night.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (raising his voice) I want a cup of tea!  15 Scene 14 Page 23.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Lower your voice, mister. We’re not the only ones here. In fact, make it yourself. You’re not an invalid.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That’s exactly what I’1l1 do. Instead, he stays seated, immobile. After a moment, Ella reaches out to smooth his hair. The gesture placates John who asks, gently now, as if he’s just thought of it for t first time:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you say - how about a cuppa tea? Ella looks up at the sky, then smiles and sighs as she ri

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I give up. She walks off.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (calls to her) Dodge 440 V8 engine, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John and Ella open the bed in the dinette, with coordinat gestures, as they’ve done so many times. Then John gets u the covers. Ella sits near him, putting drops into a glas illuminated by a small light.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Here, drink it all. She gives him two tablets that John chases down with the filled water. And then she caresses him like he’s her chi

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: John sleeps noisily back in the darkened camper. Ella sit a small table, writing what appears to be a letter on a s of paper. But then she grimaces in real pain. She pops tw blue Oxycodone pills from a blister packet and chases the down with a swig from a bottle of Canadian Club.  16 Scene 16 Page 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Taylor family’s camper starts up and rolls away, revealing the Leisure Seeker, from which John, still in pajamas, emerges to check a small water filter on the sid the camper. He nods, smiling to himself. And then he goes inside. Ella was sleeping, for the first time we see her short haircut post-chemo style. His bustling wakes her.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Good morning, Johnny my dear. She combs out her spectacular wig that has spent the nigh a Styrofoam head on the nightstand, then puts it on.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It occurred to me this morning to replace the water filter, so I did but I didn’t, amazingly the darn thing’s still clean as a whistle. He closes the door; she sits up.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I find myself compelled to admit this old contraption has its good points. There are of course, more elegant ways to travel, but there is no denying that one sleeps extremely well in that stupid bed. How about you, my princess? Did you sleep well? John’s speech seems different, more relaxed, less cataton He’s in a good mood. Ella is pleasantly surprised.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I’m so happy when you come back to me.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I was just outside. Your pain?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Where are we exactly?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Chester County, south of Philadelphia.  Scene 16 Page 24A.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Chester County? Some really beautiful country around here. Country imbued with history. It’s so good to be back on the road again. I love it. It makes us so happy. lLet’s have some coffee!  17 Scene 16 Page 25. Ella watches John as he reaches the coffee machine. But suddenly he stops and looks around, bewildered. She conti to watch him, growing worried now.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: John? He looks at her, disoriented.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s happening?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Where are we?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: (sighs) It’s so nice when you forget to be forgetful. Too bad it ends so quickly. I just can’t get used to it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Nothing. Let me make the coffee. You should get dressed, my love. John smiles at her but does not move. Ella grasps him gen by the arm and moves him toward the bed.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, slow-poke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Leisure Seeker moves down Route 1, passing the skylin of Baltimore and Washington. The road is ugly here. There car repair shops, fast food restaurants, Walmarts and che furniture outlets. Ella does not like what she’s seeing. She has the map ope her lap, while John, dressed in a checkered shirt, drives with his usual absorption.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: How ‘bout we stop at Old Chesapeake? The children loved it and you didn’t mind it so much, did you?  Scene 17 JOHN Page 26. Old what?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: The historical village in Virginia. You used to love the museum... After a moment’s silence John murmurs.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Maybe Dan isn’t, after all. Ella looks at him in confusion.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He’s not dead, is he?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Dan. You want to go to him. Ella sits in baffled silence.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Who the hell is Dan?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (very serious) We'd visit your relatives so you could secretly meet him. Ella finally understands what he’s talking about, but is still incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Oh my God... Daniel Coleman? She looks at him, expecting more, but he’s fallen silent.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (dumbfounded) What is going on in your mind?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You’re like Gretta.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Who?  Scene 17 Page 27.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: “Yes, the newspapers were right: snow was general all over Ireland...”

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: What on earth are you...?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: “It was falling on every part of the dark central plain, on the treeless hills, on the Bog of Allen and, farther westward, softly falling into the dark mutinous Shannon waves...”

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Here we go again.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: “It was falling, too, upon every part of the lonely churchyard on the hill where Michael Furey lay buried. It lay thickly drifted on the crooked crosses and headstones, on the spears of the little gate, on the barren thorns.”

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: All right ...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: “,..his soul swooned slowly as he heard the snow falling faintly through the universe and faintly falling, like the descent of their last end, upon all the living and the dead.”

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: All right, I get it, that story by Melville, you don't have to recite the whole damned thing...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: James Joyce.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I’m glad to know there are at least some things you remember well.  Scene 17 Page 28.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Gretta Conroy. You’re just like her. You’ve thought of him your whole life. Ella can’t believe this is happening. Smiling, she tells

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: What on earth are you talking about? John? She takes his arm and shakes him. He keeps his eyes on th road, muttering almost to himself.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: We'd go to Charleston and you’d slink off to Savannah. Saying you were going to see your aunt. Ella shakes her head, and then bursts into laughter.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I can’t believe this. But you should know, if Daniel Coleman is alive - and that’s a big if - he’s been living in Daytona for the past thirty years. She closely watches John, who is now driving in silence.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You hear me? She sighs, then mutters to herself, still in a state of shock.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dan Coleman. Honestly. Of all the... John, eyes fixed on the road ahead, asks:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Ella, where’s my gun? Ella watches her husband closely.  Scene 17 Page 29.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: What? We didn’t bring the gun... John doesn’t answer. Ella’s mind is working: why would he that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soldiers in eighteenth-century uniforms raise their muzzl loading muskets and shoot, producing a cloud of white smo John watches the performance. He’s in line behind Ella an other tourists at the ticket window.

dialogues.speaker: TICKET SELLER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Two people, single day. That’1l be 88 dollars, ma’am. The young man in the ticket booth, also dressed in 18th- century clothes, hands Ella a “Citizen Passport”:

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Goodness, you’ve become pricey! She reaches for her wallet.

dialogues.speaker: TICKET SELLER
dialogues.text: It’s $40.99 per ticket, plus taxes.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: When we used to come here with the kids, it was 10 dollars for the whole family.

dialogues.speaker: TICKET SELLER
dialogues.text: When was this? Back when we were a colony?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: That’s not a very nice thing to say.

dialogues.speaker: TICKET SELLER
dialogues.text: Enjoy your visit.  Scene 20. Page 30. EXT. OLD CHESAPEAKE - DAY 20. Horse-drawn carriages move through a replica 18th-century village. A military band plays:

dialogues.speaker: YANKEE DOODLE
dialogues.text: Ella and John hover near a group of tourists, as a guide describes (and perhaps exaggerates) the history of the colony. John lingers in front of a group of African-Ameri actors portraying slaves. White actors bark orders at the Ella wants to drag John away, but he resists, grumbling:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: This is awful.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Darling, come on... Ella takes him firmly by the arm and leads him toward a g of tourists entering one of the buildings.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (whispers) We have to do something to stop this outrage...

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: It’s all make-believe...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That’s just your southern racism talking.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: What utter nonsense! Come on, let’s go see the library. You used to love that. John reluctantly follows her. We notice a young woman wit two young children, a boy and a girl, in the tour group. JENNIFER. She watches John until she gets up the nerve to approach him.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: Mr. Spencer? John looks at her blankly.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s me. Jennifer Ward. Class of ‘93. How are you?  Scene 20. Page 31. Ella interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Miss, but I don’t think my husband is able to... But John perks up before she can finish.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Jenny Ward! It’s you! How the devil are you? Jennifer is almost overwhelmed with emotion.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: I am so, so happy to see you!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: How did you get on at Columbia? You must have graduated by now...

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you remember me. A surprised Ella follows the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I can’t believe it, either.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: A lot has happened since then. Michael, Emily, this is Mr. Spencer, the most inspiring teacher I ever had. The boy and girl wave shyly.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Spencer.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What was the name of that friend of yours?

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: Lorna Mitchell?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: The two of you were always laughing. Jennifer is getting emotional as she remembers.  Scene 20. Page 32.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: (sighs, perhaps a little bitterly) Yes, I was. I’m sorry if I’ve disturbed you. I’m just so happy to see you.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh, me too, Jenny. Me too! She wanders on ahead with her children. Ella, meanwhile, stares at her husband in annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: (mocking) Me too, Jenny. You can’t remember the names of your own children but you remember that Jenny was always laughing. I’m speechless. What goes on in that head of yours? She takes him away, as he says:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: She was such a good student.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 21
dialogues.text: On the road again. Ella looks tired and achy. She takes h painkillers from her purse and swallows them with a drink bottled water. John turns to her, worried.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You all right?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Yes, John. I’m just dandy. John keeps one eye on the road and one on Ella, as if studying her. Ella sighs.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who am I?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?  Scene 21 Page 33. As he says this he reaches over and touches her, is dear her.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: You're having one of your moments, aren’t you? John gives her a quizzical look.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know I’m someone dear to you, but you’re not exactly sure who. He smiles but doesn’t answer. She persists:

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Seriously, John - do you know who I am?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Of course I do. Goodness me...

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Who? Who am I? John, tell me who I am.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (laughing) Give me a second, alright? I’m thinking. Ella places a hand on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: John, tell me who I am.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You don’t know? Well I’1l tell you. You're my wife.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Very good. But what’s my name? John continues to look ahead, his eyes on the road, but h seems uneasy. Ella doesn’t stop looking at him. She’s waiting. And then it bursts out of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (snorts) Goddamnit, will you ever stop with all these stupid questions - ELLA! Then, softly repeated.  Scene 21 Page 33A.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (in dismay) Ella! My memory...

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: You knoew it. It was always there- Ella doesn't stop looking at him. She’s waiting. And then out of nowhere, it bursts out of his mouth, then is softl repeated:  Scene 21 Page 34. With the palm of his hand John hits his empty head.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Keep your eyes on the road. The Leisure Seeker rolls on toward North Carolina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ella had fallen asleep. But then:

dialogues.speaker: THE SOUND OF A HORN
dialogues.text: ++. makes her open her eyes. She realizes that the camper stopped at a green light and John is not behind the wheel She looks around the interior of the van, dazed and worri Outside the window, she can see the modest houses of a sm town. She turns to look through the back window and sees line of stalled traffic. Some of the cars go screeching around her, other drivers are out of their vehicles, curs the camper.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: (murmurs ) Good Lord, where is he now? Finally she sees him: he’s just reached the sidewalk acro the street. Patrons of a nearby bar come out to watch, curious, laughing, shaking their heads. John mixes among them, idly watching the traffic jam like it has nothing t with him. Ella slaps the windshield:

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (shouts) John! She leans on the horn. A MALE DRIVER approaches her window.

dialogues.speaker: MALE DRIVER
dialogues.text: Ma’‘am? Do you need some help?  Scene 22 Page 35. A FEMALE DRIVER has come out of her car.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE DRIVER
dialogues.text: Could I move your vehicle for you?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, please, just give me a minute... Ella opens the door, gets out and strides across the road Everybody's watching her, enjoying her distress. Ella reaches John, hissing through clenched teeth:

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Come with me, you fool. She takes him by the arm and drags him toward the camper, pushing him back on board, then hurries to get in her sid By now they are the center of attention. Everybody’s watc them, laughing. John is back behind the wheel. But he doesn’t do anything

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, drive! Can’t you see we’re holding up the whole show? John looks at the dashboard in profound confusion, as if never seen anything like this before. The gauges, the kno the lights, the key in the ignition. It might as well be cockpit of a 747. He places his hand gently on the steeri wheel, touching it as if it is made of a precious substan

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What do I do?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Turn on the engine. Come on, John, concentrate. Just turn the key. She raises her voice because once again because:

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (turns around, shouting) Just a minute! We’re leaving! (hisses at John) Please, turn the key. Get going.  Scene 22 Page 36.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Get going?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Right. Just relax. You know how to do this. You've always been a wonderful driver. But then John takes his hands off the wheel. Ella’s reall worried now. A car with flashing lights pulls up. A POLICEWOMAN gets o She's pregnant, six months at least. She approaches John’ side of the camper.

dialogues.speaker: PREGNANT COP
dialogues.text: What seems to be the problem? You're blocking traffic. You have a breakdown?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No, ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: PREGNANT COP
dialogues.text: Okay, then why aren’t you moving?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Good point, officer. John, watched by an astonished Ella, turns the key, start the motor and drives off as if nothing’s happened. An incredulous Ella bursts into laughter.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: You really are going to drive me round the bend one of these days... John, undaunted:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Did you see her? That policeman. She was pregnant!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ella sits at a picnic table scattered with brochures and maps. Sipping from a bottle of soda, she studies a Florid guidebook. She turns toward the camper and says in a rais voice:  Scene 23 Page 37.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Hey hon, did you know that Tennessee Williams had a house in Key West, too? He’s one of the writers you really love, isn’t he? I remember when you took me to the theater to see that one set in New Orleans... you hear me, John? She mutters to herself:

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Though I preferred the film with Marlon Brando. What a dish! John comes down the camper’s steps, looking alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Ella? Ella? Where are the kids?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: At home.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: We left them at the house? I can’t believe it.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: John, please... Ella understands that John is having one of his “moments.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: For God’s sake, what have we done? We've left the children on their own! Ella impatiently slams the guidebook on the table:

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: The children are all grown up! It won’t be long until they're old. They have their own lives - they’re fine.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (incredulous) Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Oh my god. Jane’s married to Philip, she teaches college. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scene 23 Page 38.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They've got two kids, a boy and a girl.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Yes, John, don’t you remember? Good heavens. Rose and Stephen.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Toddlers, right? This seems to calm him. He sits next to Ella.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They’re very cute.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: (sighs) Stephen’s nineteen and Rose is twenty-one. Don’t you remember her high school graduation ceremony? Stephen played in the band and Rosie made a wonderful speech. You were very moved by it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Stephen played... Rosie made a wonderful speech...

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: (hopeful) So you do remember.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No. I don’t. Now Ella’s really angry.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: It really hurts me that you don’t remember things. I’m sick and tired of having to remember everything for you. There’s a profound silence. A mortified John murmurs:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Forgive me, Ella. Ella realizes that she’s gone too far. Now she feels wors than he does.  24 Scene 23 Page 39.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: No, forgive me, my love. I shouldn't get angry with you.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It’s my damned memory.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I know. Come here. She takes his hand, she strokes his beard. But after seve seconds he again asks:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Ella, where are the kids? Ella sighs and stands.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Come on, there’s something we need to do. I brought along a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slightly grainy pictures from a birthday party circa 1972 Ella, in her thirties, has a kid on her knee who’s in the process of blowing out three candles.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Which one is this, John? Do you know?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It’s Jane. A slide projector on the picnic table casts images on a s strung between two oaks. Ella and John sit as if they’re the cinema. Ella works the control button on her lap. Other images appear. In one, from 1974, Ella grasps Jane' hand as she holds Will in her arms by a river.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: And where are we in this one?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Ella! Look at you! It’s true: she was very beautiful. It’s also clear that J loved to photograph her. In many of the photos, the child are cut off in the frame.  Scene 24 Page 40.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Chowan River. That marvelous camping spot at Catherine Creek. We could put up our own landmark there. Another slide. Here, finally, is John, from thirty years blurry and slightly crooked, embracing Ella.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jane took this one. John smiles. Next comes a photo which depicts a crowd of Thanksgiving guests. Ella, however, stands apart.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You were sad that evening.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I remember you telling me to make a happy face, but I just couldn’t do it. What year was that?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You were sad.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Perhaps ‘81. ‘82... She presses the control switch.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you remember these kids? She's pointing to a group of boys and girls throwing a pa for John.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Your nieces and nephews? Down in Charleston?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: No, they’re your students, throwing you a birthday party. This was your favorite class... do you remember? John says neither yes or no, but he continues to closely study the photo. Meanwhile curious campers gather around, notably an elder couple, who watch Ella’s and John’s life like it was thei own.  Scene 24 Page 41.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY WOMAN
dialogues.text: We should do this, too. We have all those slides in the basement that we never look at... And meanwhile...

dialogues.speaker: TO THE SOUND OF AN OLD STEVIE
dialogues.text: WONDER SONG ("IF IT’S MAGIC”] .». here are other photos, of trips, dinners, backyard barbecues; the happiness and melancholy of an entire life

dialogues.speaker: THE SONG CONTINUES
dialogues.text: Ella and John sleep in each others’ arms. Morning light s through the cracks in the curtains. This is perhaps what causes Ella’s eyes to fall open. She gently pulls down th covers and runs her hand along the mattress. John has wet bed. Ella shakes him awake.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: She helps him wash with a sponge, and then dry himself wi towel. Meanwhile:

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I bought you six new pairs of boxers - didn’t you see? Why don’t you wear them?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I don’t like them.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I don’t like them.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Same old song I’ve heard my whole life. What’s so great about briefs?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Control.  Scene 25 Page 42.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Hal

dialogues.speaker: THE SONG CONTINUES
dialogues.text: Outside the camper, Ella and John perform a sort of gymnastics together. Ella gives commands like a trainer. then John wanders off to parts unknown. Ella shouts after him.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, no! Where are you going? Johnnnnn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Leisure Seeker passes through fields of grapevines. I winds up at a cabin where a young farm couple with an alternative air about them sell organic grapes and grape juice.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: John and Ella are sitting at a picnic table, having a breakfast of grapes. They’re the only customers. They eat one at a time, in silence, savoring them, as cars race by At one point John plucks his handkerchief from his breast pocket and gently cleans a drop of juice from Ella’s chin

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Do you know what I love about you, John? Your silences are never embarrassing. Never once in my life have I thought: now I need to say something. It’s the thing I’ve always liked the best about our trips.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: So you still see him. John speaks this phrase abruptly, as if part of an ongoin conversation. Ella gives him a confused look:

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?  Scene 26 Page 43.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You speak with him on the phone. You write him letters.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (chuckles) Ah, so now we're pretending like you don’t know... Dan. You said he’s living in Daytona now. Ella starts to laugh again.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Dan. Oh, Dan. Susan Sullivan told us that at Maggie Tate’s funeral. You were right there beside me! John does not seem convinced.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: But you asked about him.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: What? John, the funeral was ten, no, fifteen years ago

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (sad) All these lies. All these years. John stands up and goes back into the camper, muttering, leaving Ella in amazement at the table.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: John? What are you doing? Get back here. The FARM WIFE approaches with a refill. She smiles sympathetically. Ella feels encouraged.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you believe this? He's convinced that I still think about my first boyfriend, who, by the way, dumped me. But Dan was right. Things would have never worked between us. Those were different times. I was nineteen. Oh, my lord, what a scandal...  27 Scene 26 Page 44. The hippy-farmers nod sympathetically.

dialogues.speaker: FARM WIFE
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Well they sent me to Boston to work in my Aunt Rosemary's shop. That's where I met John, this handsome young teacher who came every week to buy a new pair of leather gloves. Then he came back the next week to buy another pair - he said he’d lost them. And then he did it again. I eventually discovered he had a house full of them. Ella wants to be sure that this woman understands her sto

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He was the one for me... The woman gently asks her:

dialogues.speaker: FARM WIFE
dialogues.text: And the first boyfriend, you didn’t think about him any more? Ella considers this for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: He vanished from my mind. No, I only had eyes for John!

dialogues.speaker: GARAGE
dialogues.text: Ella dials a public phone inside a service station in Sou Carolina.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: How are you, darling? Will jumps to his feet; papers and trinkets fly off his table.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Mother, where are you? He’s answered the phone in his garage, which serves as th warehouse for his webshop. It’s packed with modern antiqu old road signs, toys, a pinball machine, Bakelite telepho  Scene 27 Page 45.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For God’s sake, tell me where you are so I can come get you immediately!

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Now listen Will. We looked at family slides last night. It was beautiful. We were looking at photos from our trip to Nantucket, where you made such good friends with that boy from New York. What was his name - Patrick?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You listen to me, Mom. Jane and I are seriously thinking about filing a missing persons report.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: He was so nice. I’ve been wondering - are you happy with your new work? You were such a good real estate broker. You were able to sell some truly ugly houses...

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Don’t change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Was it because you had a fight with your partner? You and Richard were so close... were you two ...?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You need to come back and resume your therapy. It’s crucial, mother.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Come on, Will, please talk to me about... oh Christ! Ella cannot believe what she’s seeing. Now seated behind wheel, John starts the motor and the Leisure Seeker begin move.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What did you say? Mom? But Ella has dropped the receiver without even putting it its hook. She rushes outside.  Scene 27 Page 46. Meanwhile, the camper is leaving the service area. John p on the turn signal as Ella shouts and waves...

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: John! John! Stop! STOP! ..-but he joins the highway and disappears. Will is shouting on the telephone:

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Mom! What’s happening? You’re killing me! MOTHER!!! The Young Attendant, who has begun to pump gas into a Har Davidson, looks at Ella and then looks at the camper pull away. Understanding, he begins to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: (to the Motorcyclist) Oh shit, it looks like gramps forgot his wife. A powerless Ella is in tears. She doesn’t know what to do She appeals to the Young Attendant.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Help me, please! The MOTORCYCLIST screws on his fuel cap and kick-starts h bike.

dialogues.speaker: MOTORCYCLIST
dialogues.text: Hop aboard.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: On that? How?

dialogues.speaker: MOTORCYCLIST
dialogues.text: Piece of cake. (to Young Attendant) Give her a hand, Joe. The Young Attendant practically lifts Ella in his arms. S lets him do it, and winds up riding behind the driver.

dialogues.speaker: MOTORCYCLIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hold on tight! Ella grabs onto the Motorcyclist, who rumbles off.  Scene 28 Page 47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few hundred yards down the road, they come upon the Lei Seeker, rolling briskly along. The Motorcyclist steadies bike, Ella brandishes her crutch... Inside, John turns to see through his open window this strange guy on a Harley with Ella behind him. They draw closer. John shouts, in an offended tone:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Ella, what the hell are you doing on a motorcycle? It’s dangerous for God's sake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A furious Ella sits next to John.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I don’t believe you. On a motorcycle! Without a helmet! And who was that guy?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Oh... go to hell!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: After you, ma’am! Ella stares out the window in silence, determined not to a word. After a bit John puts a hand on her knee and says

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is a lovely trip, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Go to hell, John. I mean it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (surprised) What?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: You left without me. John doesn’t seem to understand.  Scene 29 Page 48.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (xidiculous) I didn't!

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: You left me alone. Where the hell did you think you were going, you and your empty head?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Me? Going somewhere? Without you? Are you crazy? She snorts, tired of this childish bickering. They are si for a while and then John once again puts a hand on her k

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How you doing, little lady? She removes his hand, still shaken, sullen and sore. She rummages through her purse, in search of tablets. She tri to open a bottle of Pepsi but her hands are too shaky. Jo is watching out of the corner of his eye and reaches for bottle:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me. She needs to drink it to swallow her pills so reluctantly lets him take the bottle-

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Be careful, John. John smiles, puts his elbows on the horizontal steering w and steers with them as he unscrews the cap, but this act causes the Winnebago to swerve gently back and forth, sna first left towards the other lane, then right towards the shoulder, until the bottle is opened and he hands it to h

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you. Now please put both hands on the wheel. POV: The Leisure Seeker has been swerving, heading first towards the opposite lane and then back. There is no onco traffic but a Toyota traveling in the same direction as t Winnebago is compelled to slow to a crawl and loudly blow horn as the Winnebago does its Conga Line down the highwa The scene is witnessed by a cop, who hits his lights and starts to chase, passing the Toyota as he turns on:

dialogues.speaker: A SIREN
dialogues.text: Scene 29 Page 48A. Inside the camper, Ella bolts down three pills, takes a b gulp of Pepsi, then looks in the side mirror.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: John.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yup?  Scene 29 Page 49.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: You need to pull over.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You need to pee?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: The police are right behind us. John looks in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Pull over.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Why? They don’t want me...

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: (shouts) Damn it John, pull over! Finally John uses the turn signal and pulls over. He puts vehicle in PARK and TURNS OFF the engine-

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me talk, all right? I need to see if that fool son of ours snitched on us. They watch as a POLICEMAN gets out of the car and approac

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: License and registration, please.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: They're in here somewhere, officer. She stands up and opens a hatch above their heads to take a document case. As she does, we note that there’s a shot inside. She closes the door quickly and hands the documen to the cop, who examines them.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Spencer. I’ve stopped you because I saw you weaving between lanes. Ella, returning to her seat, seems relieved - Will did no call.  Scene 29 Page 50.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Excuse me, officer, it was my fault. I gave the bottle to my husband, I couldn’t open it. She shows him the Pepsi. John immediately grabs it and ta a big sip. Ella bites her lip, while the policeman looks John with astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Ma’am, if you don’t mind, I’d like for Mr. Spencer to answer himself.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (looking seriously at the policeman, engaged, eager to help) Yes, sir. I was trying to open the... the thing’n.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: The thing?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That thing. There follows a short, embarrassing silence. Ella wants t help him, but the word comes quietly to John’s head as if it’s always been there.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (as if obviously) The bottle. Another long silence, John watches the policeman as he lo closely at both passengers. And then John turns his head Ella and emits:

dialogues.speaker: A LOUD BURP
dialogues.text: Ella jolts; she’s right on the edge of losing it. The policeman, after glaring at John, says:

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: I’m going to run your license. Wait here. He walks away.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: (through clenched teeth) What are you, insane? As an answer, John puts his hand on the key and starts th engine. Ella, in desperation, reaches over, turns it off pulls the key out.  Scene 29 Page 50A.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Give me back the keys.  Scene 29 Page 51.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: (whispers) Don’t even think about it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Give them to me! Ella, getting even more worried, glances in the rearview mirror and whispers.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Zip it. He’s coming back.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: What’s going on, old timer? You thinking of running on me? He’s smiling, however, and adds: POLICEMAN (CONT’D) You wanna wind up on World’s Slowest Police Chases? Ella laughs and gently claps her hands:

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: That’s a good one, officer.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Stay in your lane and respect the speed limits, okay?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Yes, officer. Thank you so much. And have a nice day! The officer walks away.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (grumbles) Slowest Police Chase. Damned fool. Who's he think I am? O.J.? Hah! He takes the keys from Ella, puts the camper in gear and drives. Ella looks at him affectionately, her anger gone. sinks languidly into her seat as the drugs kick in.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Our old trips were never this adventurous, eh?  Scene 29 Page 52.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (a bit nonsensically) Traveling’s important. Broadening your horizons broadens your mind. Ella looks at him for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Do you love me, John? John shoots her a look.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Of course I love you. I love you, I love you, I love you.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Me too, John. Very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SCREEN: another slide show’s in progress. The subjec Will and Jane as teenagers, along with their friends. The celebrate Will’s thirteenth birthday as he blows out the candles on the cake.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: And where are we here? Ella's asking John; they sit together as if at the cinema

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (squints) At home? She’s Jane.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: And who's the one on the right?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: The littlest one. Our boy.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: He has a name, John. It’s Will.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yeah. William. Lillian is pictured during a summer backyard barbecue. Sh still attractive, posing next to Ella, both of them in shorts, their shirts tied up to expose their navels.  Scene 30 Page

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: And the woman with me is...?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (studies the picture) She lives next door?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Right. Our neighbor.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Lillian?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Well done. Meanwhile behind them someone makes: 53.

dialogues.speaker: AN APPRECIATIVE WHISTLE
dialogues.text: Ella notices a group of grungy young men approaching. The are dressed in ripped jeans, old T-shirts, unlaced sneake

dialogues.speaker: GRUNGY YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Ma’am, would it bother you if we watched as well?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Please, make yourselves comfortable! They squat nearby and pop open some beers, offering bottl to our couple.

dialogues.speaker: GRUNGY YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: We're celebrating the end of our world tour. The other guys laugh.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: What are you, some kind of rock band?

dialogues.speaker: GRUNGY YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Post-grunge-indie-folk-punk, actually.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: GRUNGY YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: It’s the kind of music we play.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: That sounds... fascinating.  Scene 30 Page 53A. And now John and Ella are drinking beer while slides play depicting their yard over the years. In one, Will turns a hose on Jane, who is nineteen and dressed in a bikini.  Scene 30 Page 54.

dialogues.speaker: MORE APPRECIATIVE WHISTLES
dialogues.text: The next one shows a pregnant Jane several years later.

dialogues.speaker: BAND
dialogues.text: Ella laughs and sips beer as she presses the button. John however, does not appreciate the whistles. Other images flow by, charting the passage of time in the yard. And then there is a more recent series, depicting John’s birthday. Jane’s there with her two kids and her husband. Will’s already balding and has a bit of a paunch. There’s also a large group of students of various ages.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You must remember this. It wasn’t that long ago. John examines the faces, but doesn’t seem to recognize an them, leaving Ella to explain them to the band members.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These are family, friends and John’s ex-students. There always seemed to be some around the house. They still come to see him years after graduating. John was a very popular teacher. And then come several close-ups of John. His unsmiling expression is distracted, far away. We’ve seen this look. The young musicians begin to get up and go.

dialogues.speaker: GRUNGY YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Good night, thanks for the show.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Yes, good night, thanks for visiting. Ella stares at John, whose eyes remain fixed on the scree Although he seems unmoved, tears trickle down his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scene A31 Page 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, smiling in his sleep, cheerfully murmurs something “Ella, where are you going .. don’t be that way, come her hey, wait ..”. He wakes from his happy dream, deeply disoriented. We see the inside of the camper through his milky, fuzzy gaze. Details come into focus: objects on th bedside table, his shoes, and then someone lying next to a back, an arm, a neck. Finally, the plucked head of Ella John shakes her gently. She opens her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Excuse me, where’s Ella?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: (patiently) I’m right here, John. John smiles incredulously and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No - Ella. Ella Carson. My girl. 22, long blonde hair. She’s gorgeous. Ella, half asleep, slowly understands what’s happening. Unnerved, she rises with some effort. She pulls her wig o loosely, drapes a sweater over her shoulders, and steppin into her shoes as if they were slippers she leaves the ca without a word. Left alone, dazed, John tries to focus on his location as dream fades. He gets up and leaves the motor-home. Outside, he spots Ella sitting alone on a park bench in t moonlight, her back to him.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that really you, Ella? She answers with controlled fury.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Of course it’s me. Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I’m me. John.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Oh no, you’re not.  31 32 Scene A31 Page 56. John steps in front of her, with a hesitant smile, as if say: look at me, it is me. Ella does not return his smile She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My John is a young teacher. He’s charming and educated and very handsome. And I want him back. You stole him from me and I want him back. Give him back to me! John considers her words. He sits next to her.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Boy, I would if I could. But whoever stole him from you stole him from me, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first light of morning filters through the windows. E opens her eyes and realizes she’s alone.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: John? She struggles out of bed. She opens the curtains, then op the camper door and peers outside. John isn’t there.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (louder) John? Something tells her to open the door of the cabinet where hides the shotgun. It’s there. Ella looks relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ella addresses a young man behind the reception desk.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Excuse me, but you haven’t by any chance seen my husband passing by? He’s tall, distinguished-looking, with a white beard and glasses. The guy watches her, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: A guy like that passed by here ‘pout a half hour ago.  33 Scene 32 Page 57.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: And where was he going?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: No idea ma‘am.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I’m afraid I’1l need your help, then. My husband suffers moments of memory loss, and I’m afraid he may wander off and get hurt.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Maybe you should call the cops?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: But don’t you have a car so we can have a quick look around? He can’t have gone far.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: I can’t leave my post. Why not use your camper?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: It’s too big, I can’t handle it. Please, I wouldn’t ask you if it wasn’t important.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Lemme call my brother Terry. He dials a number on his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ella sits in the cab of a pick-up driven by a tattooed yo man - TERRY. His bleached hair is gathered in a ponytail; wears many rings, bracelets and necklaces. They are scour the streets of the seaside town.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: (to herself) It’s my fault. My fault. The boy points to an old homeless man who sleeps leaning against the trunk of a palm tree.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (excited) Hey, is that him?  Scene 33 Page 58.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Who, that poor geezer? Oh no, darling, I’ve told you, my John is a very distinguished gentleman. Glasses, well-groomed beard...

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I get it. Academic from Yankee- land. I like that type. Ella watches Terry with a knowing smile.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I think my son is a lot like you.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Like me?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: You're gay, right? Don’t worry, I know it’s not a disease. We should all be more gay. Happier. It’sa gift from God. Terry laughs and nods.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: You think maybe this God could gift me blue eyes and make me six inches taller? Ella speaks as she continues to scrutinize passersby:

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Will’s never wanted to accept himself. Or maybe he’s never understood himself. It’s such a shame. Maybe he’d have been happier, more cheerful if he had. You want nothing more than to know your children are happy, especially after you’re gone...

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Will’s lucky to have a Mom like you.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, he won’t have a mother like me for much longer.  Scene 33 Page 59.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Don’t say that - you look pretty fit to me. That wig is awesome.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: What makes you think I’m wearing a wig? Terry gives her a double-take and Ella laughs. She continues to search, but she is also lost in a memory

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A few months ago I came home and found a shotgun on the kitchen table. It gave me such a fright! John was calmly watching football on TV. When I asked him what the gun was doing there, he couldn’t answer. Later I found a note, but all that was written on it was “Ella my love” followed by some scribbles. And then I understood. Silence. The boy is intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: (mutters ) For such an intelligent man to feel his brain fading away... But suddenly she lights up, her eyes wide, shouting, besi herself with joy.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There he is! Stop! She points to a seafront ice cream shop, where John sits table. The pick-up enters the parking lot, stopping practically meter away from John. Terry helps Ella descend.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: John! He turns to look at her, but does not seem to recognize h He returns his attention to his cup of chocolate ice crea Ella reaches him and embraces him. She starts to cry.  Scene 33 Page 60.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus, John!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Why are you crying?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Because you weren’t there. I wouldn’t know how to live without you, not for a minute. We have to stick together. Understand? We don’t have much time left.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (serenely) Then it’s a good thing you came cause you wouldn’t want to miss this. One helluva chocolate ice cream. Ella turns to Terry, who looks amused and a bit moved by scene.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Have a seat, ma’am. I’1ll go get you your ice cream. Ella, crying, changes the order.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I'd prefer a whisky. EXT. CAMPSITE, JEKYLL ISLAND - ENTRANCE - DAY 34. The Leisure Seeker, with John and Ella aboard, exits thro the campsite’s gates and drives off. Ella salutes through window. Terry waves cheerfully. His brother gives a more sober no

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Leisure Seeker moves through the coastal regions of Georgia. The road is lined by forests of Spanish moss-cov trees. These are interrupted by swamps of tall grass. The are signs warning swimmers and fishermen of Poisonous Sna and Alligators.

dialogues.speaker: SONG
dialogues.text: Scene 35 Page 61.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: (she is saying)... it was cold, but it was beautiful. Remember? Everything was covered by a layer of ice, shiny and transparent, like the world had been covered with glass. I had to take tiny steps to keep from slipping. I was so cold, but you wanted to go on. You were telling me the story of White Fang, keeping your voice low, so you wouldn’t spoil the perfect silence. We got home at three in the morning, our hair full of frost. That was the night we made Jane... The camper starts to sway. John struggles to keep the steering wheel steady.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Can’t you keep it straight? In the cabin, objects begin to fall, plates and jars shak and slam. John slows down and pulls over.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It’s all right. Just a flat.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The road is completely deserted. There is no sign of life John, sweaty and with dirty hands, crouches in front of a flat tire. He tries in vain to turn the jack handle. Ella approaches, wrapping up a phone conversation.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: (on the phone) «--good, we’ll be waiting for you. Yes, mile marker 21. Thanks! She hangs up the phone and turns to John.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s okay, hon. Triple A will be here in half an hour. And I think the spare is flat, anyway. We’1l need a tow.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I don’t need them.  Scene 35 Page 62.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I know you don’t, but we’re on vacation, right? Come on inside, don’t stay out here roasting in the sun. While moving toward the cockpit they are passed by an old Plymouth, which slows and stops a little further down the road, then turns back. Two kids get out, approaching with shambling steps. They young, not even twenty. Scrawny and white.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh my god, John. These guys are scaring me.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Can’t you see they’re just a couple of kids?

dialogues.speaker: FIRST KID
dialogues.text: You folks need a hand? John looks at Ella: you see? But Ella quickly says:

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: No thanks, fellas. Triple A will be here soon.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND KID
dialogues.text: How long ‘til they get here?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (obliviously) Half an hour if we’re lucky.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND KID
dialogues.text: Good. He pulls out a knife.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: (whispers) John, you fool.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST KID
dialogues.text: Just be cool. We’re going to take your shit and then we'll go.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND KID
dialogues.text: Gimme that phone!  Scene 35 Page 63. He points to the cell in Ella’s hand. She hands it to him SECOND KID (CONT’D) Your ring, too. Now the other guy’s pulled out a knife. He approaches Joh

dialogues.speaker: FIRST KID
dialogues.text: Where’s your wallet at, old man?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Never end a sentence with a preposition. When you say ‘where’ the ‘at’ is implied... Wham! He’s silenced with a slap.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: (terrified) John, just do what they say. She slips off her ring and gives it to the Second Kid. An then she raises her hands, motioning to John to do the sa

dialogues.speaker: SECOND KID
dialogues.text: And you, old woman, shut up and give me your purse.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: It’s in the camper. Shall I get it? He gives her permission with a wave. She obeys.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND KID
dialogues.text: Just move slowly, all right?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: As if I have a choice. She disappears into the camper. Meanwhile John has raised his hands. The First Kid is try to pull the wallet from John’s pocket.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST KID
dialogues.text: Fuck, it’s huge. You win the lottery, old man? He slices John’s pocket open with the knife. He pulls out enormous wallet, gives it a quick disappointed look, then turns to his companion. His expression changes immediatel  Scene 35 Page 64.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST KID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ah, shit. Ella has come out of the camper holding the shotgun, whic she points at the Second Kid. The First Kid grabs John and holds the knife to his throa

dialogues.speaker: FIRST KID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Put down the fucking gun or I hurt him bad. But Ella continues to wield the shotgun confidently, poin it first at one, and then at the other.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: If you hurt him I’11 shoot you both. And if you think we’re afraid you're dead wrong. I - no, we - have nothing to lose. So drop the knives, you hooligans. At that moment there’s a sound... THE CHIRPY RING OF ELLA’S

dialogues.speaker: CELLPHONE
dialogues.text: ...in the hand of the First Kid, who looks at the display

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s Will, right?

dialogues.speaker: FIRST KID
dialogues.text: (nods ) I ain’t answering it.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Well I don’t want to talk to him. He’s always calling at the wrong time. Toss it on the ground. The two kids exchange an uncertain look and we realize th they’re not professionals. The telephone stops ringing.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Sweetheart, make sure the safety’s off before you start shooting, okay?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Already done it, hon, thanks. The First Kid drops the knife.  Scene 35 Page 65.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST KID
dialogues.text: Let’s go, Cody. Just give them back their shit. He throws the wallet on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Please do as he says, Cody. Put the ring on the wallet and get along. I won’t even call the cops if you leave now. Hurry along. After a moment’s hesitation, he obeys, leaving the ring a the cellphone. After one last disbelieving look the two o them move briskly away.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND KID
dialogues.text: Your ring sucked anyway.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST KID
dialogues.text: And your wallet’s full of bullshit. As they get into their car, John shouts after them:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You fellas should consider evening classes. Get your diplomas! Turn things around. S’not too late! The Plymouth peels away. There’s a moment of silence. Ell still has the shotgun pointed.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good thing we had the gun. I was afraid we'd left it at home.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I thought we might need it. Now - I need a Canadian. Could you get it from the fridge please? John obeys. Ella takes the opportunity to remove the shel from the gun and throw them as far as she can into the surrounding fields.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAMPER/ EXT. COLLEGE CAMPUS
dialogues.text: A tow truck pulls the Leisure Seeker through a vast flat rural landscape.  Scene 36 Page 66. On board the camper, John and Ella sit cheerfully. They celebrate the success of their misadventure by passing a bottle of Canadian Club. Ella’s on the phone:

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Yes, darling, I know that your brother called. I didn’t answer because I was... held up. John smiles - he appreciates the pun. Jane speaks on her cell phone while striding across the campus of the college where she teaches. She juggles the phone and her paper-stuffed shoulder bag.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: We're really worried, mother. Will’s getting desperate. I’m going to see him now.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Your brother is a Nervous Nelly. It’s nice of you to stay near him. Tell him that your father and I are having a grand old time. Jane's a bit amused by her mother’s response.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: So where are you, Mom?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Darling, I wish you could see the sky here.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Okay, I get it, you aren’t going to tell me. How’s Dad? Ella shoots a look at her husband, who’s taking a big sip Canadian Club.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Full of beans. Oh, he still has his moments. But he’s doing well and he’s driving, which is a miracle. Would you like to speak with him? Ella passes the phone to her husband.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s Jane - she wants to speak with you.  Scene 36 Page 67.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Your daughter! Take it. John takes the phone and cheerfully shouts:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Hey, Pumpkin! How are you? Jane is so moved that she is forced into a moment’s silen

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I don’t think you’ve called me that since I was eight, Daddy. She stops in her tracks. Floored by her father’s words.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're being careful, right?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You've been so much in my head these days, little one. Do you have any idea how proud I am of you. I bet you’re making a big splash at your college. It’s not for nothing you’re named Spencer.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Yes, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I love you, Pumpkin. We’1l see you soon... He passes the phone hastily to his wife.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Jane?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Mom.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I love you, too.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Me too, Mom. You make sure you come home, okay?  37 Scene 36 Page 68.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Kiss the kids for me. And tell your brother we’ve spoken. A choked-up Jane can hardly speak.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I’1l be sure to do that, Mom. Ella hangs up. She, too, has misty eyes. She says to John

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Hey, don’t finish all the Canadian. She snatches it from his hand. INT. WILL’S GARAGE - DAY 37

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Leave them alone. They’re having fun. She says this to Will, who shakes his head. They’re sitti on a zebra-striped sofa in his garage ‘office.’

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, allow me to introduce Jane the All-Knowing. Watch her explain everything to poor Will. Who doesn’t know Jack Shit.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (smiles, sighs) What the hell are you talking about? I’m just telling you that there’s nothing we can do to stop them. It’s her right to refuse treatment. We both know how little good it is now, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I know that it’s better than wandering around god-knows-where in a creaky camper. But you know best, I guess, because you talked to Dad, and you two are thick-as-thieves, even when he doesn’t even remember who we are.  Scene 37 Page 69.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I don’t understand why you’re making this so personal, Will...

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Because you live two hours away and phone once a week and come on weekends for lunches that are cooked by me. What do you know about spending long afternoons with Dad when he doesn’t say a single thing that makes sense? Do you know what Mom says when she gets sick and I have to run there in the middle of the night? You know what she says when I get there? Don’t call Jane. She’s busy.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: You've been telling this story about how I’m Daddy’s Girl for years. It’s bullshit, Will.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Maybe it is. But it’s the only story I’ve got.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: They're just doing what they’ve done their whole life. Staying together, the two of them. Jane wants to hug him, but Will backs away in a sulk.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: There’s so much love between them that they forgot about us. Both of us.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Oh Will.. Jane sighs at the sight of her brother’s fragility.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: So you know what happened, when was it, last year? I opened their bedroom door and she was on the bed and he was kneeling in front of her and... I can’t even say it.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (smiling) Dad was muff diving? Yodelling in the canyon?  Scene 37 Page 70.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (shivers) I wanted to vomit.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (laughing) Why? I hope it happens to me when I'm their age. Will buries his head in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: God, what a thought. Jane is struck by a melancholy thought about her life.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Though I kinda doubt it. For years now, with Philip and me, it’s one quick kiss and goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flat tire has been repaired and the Leisure Seeker is back on the road. Ella continues to write on the pad of p resting on her knees. But she raises her eyes because the camper suddenly slows down: the road is filled with participants in a Republican election rally.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Houston, we have a problem.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Just pull over. We can wait. Hemingway isn’t going anywhere. There are red hats that read ‘MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN;’ shirts and banners with the grinning face of the Republic candidate.

dialogues.speaker: PEOPLE ARE YELLING SLOGANS
dialogues.text: John is forced to pull over.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Wanta go see.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: What’s to see? You know who these people are.  Scene 38 Page 71.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I want to have a look - John is out of the vehicle in an instant, and Ella’s too tired to chase after him. All she can do is yell:

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Don’t go far! John turns and gives her an OK sign, smiling. And then he asks someone what’s going on.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A little later, John wears a ‘Make America Great Again’ h drinks beer and toasts rabid supporters as they shout slo like:

dialogues.speaker: REPUBLICAN SUPPORTERS
dialogues.text: - The only good terrorist is a dead terrorist. - This land is our land! - No more Muslims! Ban them all! - Build a wall too tall for Mexicans! Each of these slogans is greeted by a joyous ‘Yes!,’ whic John echoes with real conviction, as if it were a funny g he didn’t understand. This carries on until a hand grabs arm to pull him away:

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: John, please, come with me.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: But this is so much fun!

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Yes, I know, but it’s better that you come with me now. We’re gonna get a parking ticket. As she begins to drag him away, John shouts:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: See you later, everybody! Make America great again! Those gathered nearby raise their beer bottles to toast J

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Scene 38 Page 72. John and Ella are once again in the camper. They are leav the road is once again passable.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: John, they were Republicans.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (nodding agreement) Uh-huh...

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: You’ve voted Democrat your whole life. You volunteered for Walter Mondale. Don’t you remember how mad you got when I talked about voting for Reagan?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Ray-gun... ha, that’s funny -

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Don’t you remember him?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (thinks, then nods) Sure, I remember.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: That’s not true. You don’t have the slightest idea. Who am I? John’s mouth falls open. He smiles and looks at her but h name is not coming to him.  39 Scene 38 Page 73.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (patiently) Think, John. You know my name very well. It starts with - There is a pause and then John looking at her suggests -

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Right. Ell. Go on. It’s on the tip of John’s tongue.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Lillian!

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Sweet Jesus, now you think I’m Lillian? Lillian is our next door neighbor. I’m your wife. L? LA?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
