dialogues.text: Ella. My darling Ella. Excuse me. Oh, wow, my poor head. Ella continues to stare at him, trying to understand what going on inside his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The projector's carousel turns. All the slides are of Jan and Will: swimming in the ocean, stuffing cake into their mouths at a birthday party, Trick-or-Treating, rolling in piles of raked leaves, posing rigidly by the fireplace, sitting on Santa’s lap at a shopping center, close-up portraits... Ella and John are once again seated outside the Leisure Seeker like they’re at a cinema. There are no other campe around, only the deep coniferous woods that surround the camp. John eats a sandwich, while Ella swallows a blue painkiller. There’s no commentary from her this time, no narration. She’s not in a good way. And then John opens h mouth:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Look how cute Jane was! Ella smiles and nods yes, happy that John is enthusiastic Next comes a photo of Will sitting on the shoulders of a tall, handsome man with an intelligent expression.  Scene 39 Page 74.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, look - that’s Jim! But then his expression darkens. He asks Ella:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How’s Jim these days?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Jim passed, hon. Last July. We went to see him at that human warehouse where he spent his last two years, remember? (she sighs) Unfortunately, he didn’t recognize us. John thinks, trying to remember. He murmurs:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That’s terrible. Poor Jim. Ella watches him, trying to read his thoughts. And then J looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Promise me something.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: If you love me, when the time comes, put the shotgun in my hands, put my finger on the trigger, remind me what I want to do, kiss me and walk away. It’s like mud season in Massachusetts. Messy but necessary. Ella reaches out and firmly grips her husband's hand. She presses the button to continue the show, but the caro is at its end. White light almost blinds them. John instinctively pulls out the power cord to kill the painfu light, leaving them in near-darkness.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: John, what have you done? Put it back in.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I can’t find the outlet.  Scene 39 Page 75. And then they hear what sounds like an animal in the bush

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Unlikely it’s an alligator. He'd be on us by now.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Oh my god - an alligator?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Let’s get the gun. Ella rises.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Let’s go inside. Muttering to herself.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We don’t have any shells... She heads toward the camper, but she trips and takes a di

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Ella?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Help me, John. I think I’ve pulled something in my back. I’m down here on the ground. Help me get up.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh shit! John approaches Ella and extends his hand.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Give me your hand.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: John, I can’t do it like that.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Give me your hand. Ella grabs John’s hand. He tries to pull her up, but he l his balance and falls on top of her. They remain like thi on the ground, a situation comic and dire at the same tim  Scene 39 Page 76.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Get up! You’re crushing me.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I hurt my arm.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: So what? Get off! John gathers all his strength and manages to roll off her Now they are side-by-side on the ground, with no strength left. They look at one another.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What’re we doing on the ground?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I fell! Don’t you even remember? You tried to help me and you fell, too.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh, shit.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: We need to try to reach the camper. Can you move?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Nope. Can’t do it. Ella does not lose heart. She begins to crawl toward the vehicle. The stones hurt; she’s soon covered in mud and d But gradually she approaches the steps. She grabs on and tries to pull herself up, but fails.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I can’t do it. Get up and get over here and help me. John does not respond.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: John? Nothing. And so she makes another effort. She plants an e on the ground and clings to the steps with her free hand she can turn around and rest her back against the steps. at least she’s sitting up. She looks at John. She can’t believe it - he’s asleep, right there on the ground.  Scene 39 Page 77. Snoring, as if tucked snugly in his bed. She begins to pi up pebbles and toss them at him until the snoring stops. stirs and then, after a direct hit, angrily says:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Are you crazy? What are you trying to do, stone me to death?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I hurt my back. You need to get over here and help me up. I can’t do it on my own. He pulls himself up - it seems as if that quick nap has helped him recover. But instead of going over to help Ell he approaches the projector.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Hey, the projector’s unplugged... Ella screams at him at the top of her lungs.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: JOHN! Move your ass and help me! Finally, John gets up and goes to her. She holds out her when he leans over, but he doesn’t even see her. Instead, lowers himself even further, toward her shoes.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What on earth are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Your shoes are untied. He begins to tie her shoes with care.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Thank you, John.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: With everything you do for me? This is nothing - He gets up and kisses her on the mouth. And then he begin gently wipe the dirt off her face.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're all dirty. He gives her a gentle pat.  Scene 39 Page 78.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What would I be without you? You want to know? Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Don’t exaggerate. Sure, lately you’ve needed my help, but... John smiles sweetly, shaking his head no.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It’s been this way our whole lives. Without you I couldn’t have done anything, my darling, darling little one. My goodness, look how sexy you are - Ella has to swallow back the lump rising in her throat. J has always been affectionate, but only in his brusque, dr manner. He’s never used an endearment like that with her. order not to be overwhelmed by emotion, she waves her arm as if it’s a big joke.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: How about a little pick-me-up?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That sounds like an excellent idea. This time he grabs her beneath her arms and, just like th they’re both on their feet again. He helps her slowly cli the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ella is sleeping, but a noise inside the van disturbs her she opens her eyes. John isn’t beside her. She looks at t time on the electronic alarm clock, then lifts the curtai Outside, the chairs and table are missing.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: John? What’s the big rush to go? She pulls herself up with great difficulty.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I could've used a little more sleep. John? Oh my God. Her eyes widen. She’s confronted with an unlikely sight: is pointing the shotgun at her. He’s already dressed and a deeply serious expression.  Scene 40 Page 79.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It’s the moment of truth, Ella...

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: For heaven’s sake, what is this?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Take me to him. Now.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: To who?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: To whom. To Dan. Dan Coleman. I need to look him straight in the eye. Ella's not worried about the gun - she knows it’s empty.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: John, for God's sake.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I’m not going to wait for some snowy night for you to finally confess everything as you look out the window at the snow falling faintly through the universe - Ella pulls herself up impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I’m getting so sick of this nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He was always there for you. Dan! I was only ever second-best. John’s words come as a revelation that makes Ella shudder she feels compassion for him, but also anger.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: How dare you point a gun at me!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Take me to him.  Scene 40 Page 80. Ella leaps to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I’ve had enough! I’m sorry you've been thinking this all these years but ... you want to see Dan Coleman? Fine! She grabs her cell phone from her bag.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I’m going to find out where the hell Dan is - even if he’s in his grave - and take you to him.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You will? Finally! She dials a number and then looks at him as she puts the phone to her ear.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Well, don’t just stand there. Start the damned engine.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh, I will! 4l EXT. RESIDENTIAL CARE CENTER, DAYTONA - DAY 41 The camper arrives at the entrance of a residential care center for the elderly.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: (speaking with John) You can’t go in there with a gun!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I’m going in as I see fit.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Fine. Take it. A hundred cops will show up and probably kill us both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An African-American Receptionist raises her eyes from a computer screen.  Scene 42 Page 80A.

dialogues.speaker: CENTER RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: May I help you?  Scene 42 Page 81.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: We'd like to see Daniel Coleman, please. I believe he’s a resident here? Ella forces a reassuring smile. John frowns, and there’s strange bulge in the left side of his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: CENTER RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Daniel Coleman?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: CENTER RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Are you on the list?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: We're old friends. We were just passing by.

dialogues.speaker: CENTER RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: One moment, please.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: You're very kind. The receptionist rises from her post and enters an office Ella's forced smile becomes a worried grimace when she realizes that John has begun to walk down the corridor on own, his pace lopsided due to what’s hidden in his jacket She walks behind him.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, she said to wait. John doesn’t answer. He opens the first of a long series doors along the corridor and looks inside: there’s an emaciated old man seated at a table, peeling an apple.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Is that you, Coleman? The old man gives him a strange look. Ella reaches John.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, we seem to have the wrong room.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Who you looking for?  43 Scene 42 Page 82.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: We don’t want to disturb you... But John will not be denied.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Daniel Coleman. You know him? Which room is his? INT. DAN’S ROOM, RESIDENTIAL CARE CENTER, DAYTONA - DAY. Another room, where Old Man 2, glasses perched on his rud nose, lies in bed listening to:

dialogues.speaker: A HAPPY SONG ON THE RADIO
dialogues.text: (MAGIC MOMENTS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .-. and another man, seen from behind, seated in a wheelchair, seems mesmerized by something outside the win The door opens and John peers inside, followed by Ella.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Finally, we find you! Both old men turn. We can now see the face of the one sea in the wheelchair: he’s a skinny black guy in his eightie with oxygen tubes stuck in his nostrils. John points the shotgun toward the man on the bed, who raises his hands. Ella tries to hold John back, but it’s too late:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve always wanted to see your face, Dan Coleman. Old Man 2 responds, his hands in the air.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN 2
dialogues.text: But I’m not Dan. The black man has his hands raised as well. John, getting disoriented, looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you people?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: It’s Ella. Ella Carson. Do you remember me?  Scene 43 Page 83.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Ella? Who the hell is Ella? What do you want from me? (shouts) Nurse! Help! Ella shushes him. John’s not understanding any of this.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Where’s Daniel Coleman?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: That’s me. But who the hell are you? Meanwhile, Old Man 2 looks terrified, his hands still rai John looks at Ella in confusion:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That’s him? But Ella is now gripped by another thought. She continues speak to Dan.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Do you really not remember me? This is my husband John Spencer. John continues to point his gun at Dan as he incongruousl says:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you. Dan stares at him, convinced he’s dealing with two lunati As if to confirm this:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you wear boxers?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Do you wear boxers or briefs?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: This is what you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: What the hell is he saying?  Scene 43 Page 84.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (to Ella) I want to understand where this fixation with boxers comes from.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: All right, then - ask away.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Do you wear boxers or briefs? Dan lowers his hands. This is crazy. Meanwhile, on the ra

dialogues.speaker: PERRY COMO CONTINUES TO SING
dialogues.text: ‘MAGIC MOMENTS’

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I wear diapers. (to Ella) Ella who? I don’t remember any Ella.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: You don’t remember me? Shoot this son of a bitch, John. The door opens. The very worried Center Receptionist and Nurse peer inside.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (whispers) John, put that thing away. The Receptionist and the Nurse throw open the door.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: What’s going on here?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He doesn’t remember my wife. Ella grabs the gun from John and tells the two newcomers:

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, it’s empty.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It is? But the women grab John and lock the door.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Wait, he’s not dangerous - he’s an English teacher!  44 Scene 43 Page 85. The nurse brusquely grabs the gun from Ella’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (to Ella) But who the hell are you? Ella who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ella and John are led to the camper by the Receptionist, Nurse, a male MEMBER OF STAFF and a man with the uniform security guard, who returns the gun to John.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Next time you come to visit your friend, do it without this, even if it is empty.

dialogues.speaker: CENTER RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Just be grateful we didn’t call the police.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: You've been very understanding.

dialogues.speaker: MEMBER OF STAFF
dialogues.text: We were thinking that perhaps the two of you might need a little rest. No offense intended. He shows Ella a brochure describing the facility’s amenit MEMBER OF STAFF (CONT’D) This contains a list of all the insurance we accept. We’ll call your children so they can come tour the facility...

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: That's very nice of you. We’l1l think about it.

dialogues.speaker: MEMBER OF STAFF
dialogues.text: But are you sure you want to be travelling around on your own? It’s nice here. Ask Dan. The Receptionist is getting embarrassed at her colleague' insistence.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Come on, Brian...  45 Scene 44 Page 86. John, meanwhile, has helped Ella climb the steps. He then gets behind the wheel. The Leisure Seeker lurches away as the others watch with amazed, amused and worried expressions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While driving the camper, John strokes Ella’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Why are you so sad?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I’m just a little tired. She masks a grimace, then throws down another painkiller.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But yes, I’m also angry. At you, mostly, but also at Dan.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Dan? Dan who?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Oh, for Christ’s sake!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh right. The guy who isn’t in Savannah any more. After a long silence.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He was black? Ella looks at him, then starts to laugh. John laughs, too perhaps without even knowing why.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: He was a little more charismatic than this at the time. The camper now passes by a Democratic rally. We might eve glimpse Hillary speaking; an echo of her speech reaches t

dialogues.speaker: AMPLIFIED VOICE OF HILLARY
dialogues.text: But the Spencers aren't interested. Ella has stopped laughing; her expression is darkened by suffering. She’s really tired and hurting.  46 Scene 45 Page 87.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: John?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Let’s sleep in a real bed tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the reception area of a high-end Radisson, Ella approa the reception desk while John looks around with cheerful curiosity. The HOTEL RECEPTIONIST welcomes them with a ceremonious tone.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Good evening, ma’am. How might I assist you?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Good evening. Could we have a nice room that’s... (hesitates) economical?

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: I'm afraid there’s not much left. (checks his computer) Half the state seems to be here to watch Hillary. We do have a standard double with twin beds.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Oh, no, we can’t be separated.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: In that case we have the deluxe suite, which has two kings, but that’s...

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: We'll take it.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: «+. that’s normally five hundred dollars a night ... but I can let you have it for three-twenty, plus tax.  47 Scene 46 Page 88.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Heavens, we don’t want to buy it, just spend the night. The Receptionist hesitates before bursting into laughter. hands him the credit card.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We've never spent that much on a hotel room in my whole life. The Receptionist pretends not to have heard her as he han her the room key card.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: You're in 723. Artie will show you. Do you have luggage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room’s lights come on. ARTIE carries the bag Ella has packed for the night, while the two guests take in their luxury room. It is new and huge, decorated in beige and g tones. There’s a lounge beyond the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: ARTIE
dialogues.text: I hope this will be to your liking. There’s a minibar. You also have a DVD player and a stereo. And in here’s the master bedroom... Artie puts their bag into the master bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It’s a beautiful room. Can we afford it?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) What are you saying, John? Of course we can afford it. She rummages through her purse to get a tip, but Artie wa her off.

dialogues.speaker: ARTIE
dialogues.text: Enjoy your stay. He leaves. Ella immediately turns on the stereo, looking a song she likes, and finds: ‘DON’T LEAVE ME THIS WAY’ BY

dialogues.speaker: THELMA HOUSTON
dialogues.text: 48 Scene 47 Page 89.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: And now a little something to help us sleep. Ella opens the minibar and finds a bottle of champagne. S removes it.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you say, John? I think we've earned it. She gives the bottle to John, who whistles when he sees i Ella gets two glasses. John opens the bottle, pours champagne. They toast, while: ‘DON’T LEAVE ME THIS WAY”

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUES
dialogues.text: And then they kiss. John makes her do a pirouette; Ella, laughing, tries to escape. But John insists. She does a pirouette, then another.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Come on, darling, boogie with me. And then she collapses in his arms, leans forward and vom

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ella...

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Oh my God, I’ve ruined the carpet. In shock, she starts to clean it with her blouse, but Joh lifts her up and gently wipes her mouth with his handkerchief. And all the while: “DON’T LEAVE ME THIS WAY”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The following morning Ella wakes to the voice of John mumbling from afar. She checks the clock: it’s late.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Hon?  Scene 48 Page 90. She gets up and finds John in the luxurious bathroom, whe already washed and dressed, he’s combing his hair in fron the mirror as he describes Santiago of The Old Man and th Sea.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: ‘The old man was thin and gaunt and had deep wrinkles in his neck. The brown blotches of the benevolent skin cancer the sun brings from its reflection on the tropic sea were on his cheeks. The blotches ran well down the sides of his face and his hands had the deep-creased scars from handling heavy fish on the cords. But none of these scars were fresh. They were as old as erosions in a fishless desert.’ Ella stands there, watching. When he realizes she’s there

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good morning, honey, you sleep well?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Like a rock. When’s the last time I slept this late?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Okay, I’m off, I’ll be back at the usual time...

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Where are you going? He kisses her, exits the room and heads down the corridor Ella follows him in confusion. She stops at the door, watching as he waves goodbye. But after a few steps he freezes, lost. He turns to her:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: But this isn’t our house.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Where are we?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: In a good place.  49 Scene 48 Page 91.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: This good place have tea?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I was thinking the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 49 Ella walks back to the table with a tray of croissants. S finds John has buttonholed a YOUNG WAITRESS, who listens a polite smile.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Santiago is the perfect character. He achieved the inner spiritual success that defines Hemingway's ‘true man’. To be defeated but not destroyed. When we get to the end of the story Hemingway’s watching the old man lying there, sound asleep, the skeleton of his great fish still on his line, and he writes...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WAITRESS
dialogues.text: “The old man was dreaming about lions”.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (over the moon with delight at discovering a kindred soul) You know it!

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Excuse me, can I have a clean spoon?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WAITRESS
dialogues.text: I wrote my honors thesis on Old Man and the Sea.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I loved the movie with Spencer Tracy. What an impressive man.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Hemingway’s house is in Key West.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (thrilled) That's where we're going!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scene 49 Page 91A.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WAITRESS
dialogues.text: I’ve always wanted to go there.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WAITRESS
dialogues.text: There’s a quote of William Faulkner's where he says Hemingway was “one of the bravest and the best” -

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: terjecting) And add on to that for me: “one of the purest”!  Scene 49 Page 92.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Oh, I totally agree.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I’m sure you do. Now how about that spoon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Leisure Seeker travels down a coastal road lined with palm trees. Palm Beach's skyline serves as backdrop. Ella's sick; she cannot stop herself from grimacing. John notices what’s happening. He pulls to the side of the roa

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Don’t stop, John. Let’s find a campsite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, after setting them up, John helps Ella into bed in camper. He takes off her shoes.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, but I really do need to lie down. If you’re hungry, there’s some cheese in the fridge. John does not answer - he’s too focused on being attentiv Finally, Ella’s lying comfortably. John asks, tenderly:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You better now, Lillian?  Scene 51 Page 93. Ella looks at him, struck by the fact that John called he that name once again.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I won’t go home quite yet. Don’t fret, I won’t leave you alone until you're okay. A inspired thought crosses Ella’s mind. She decides to be Lillian:

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Where’s Ella now?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Ella? Ella’s at home.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: At home?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Baby’s taking its toll. I should be there. Good God. I’m not right. I better go to her. Ella's trying hard to stay calm. She swallows back her pr and continues.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Wait. Does Ella know about us?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You know she doesn’t. I mean, I couldn’t bear it if Ella knew. Neither could you. It’d break her heart. Mine, too. I’m so selfish- The question has stirred John up.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ella must never know! Never. We have to stop this, Lillian. Ella experiences a pang to the heart and can barely hold her tears. But she needs to know everything.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Yes, we must stop. It’s gone on a long time.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Too long, I guess, yes...  Scene 51 Page 94.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: How long is too long? John sighs as he thinks back.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: We said it’d be only the once and it’s been nearly two years now-

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: But do you love me? John shakes his head and looks at her sadly.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Lillian, we’ve talked about this and you agreed. We’re wonderful friends. The best, but I love Ella. We're expecting another baby. Ella collapses back on the pillow. She’s desperate now.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ella's the love of my life, she’s everything to me. We’ve another baby on the way, for god’s sakes. Ella knows that she’s hearing a great declaration of love but she’s too angry to care. John extends his arms. Deepl moved, he says:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, but goodbye, dear Lillian goodbye - He leaves the camper with a bowed head. Ella rises cursin from the bed.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch! Where are you going? Get back here! Come here so I can kill you! As she screams she grabs objects, dishes, anything at han throwing it all on the ground. John, hearing the commotion, rushes back in.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Ella, what's happening?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Oh, so now I’m Ella again? Damn you!  Scene 51 Page 95. She begins to strike him with all her remaining strength.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (protecting himself) What are you doing? Why are you so mad? What’s happened? Ella dials a number, calling someone at reception.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Good evening, I’m calling from space 37. Could you please send a taxi here a.s.a.p? Thank you. She hangs up in a fury. John watches her blankly as she begins to pack a bag, filling it with his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (disoriented) Ella, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Quiet, fool. Our trip ends here. As usual, when she turns on her phone, someone calls. Ell grabs it and shouts:

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Will - what the hell do you want? Just leave me alone! And then she turns off her phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi approaches the Leisure Seeker. A confused John sta in front of it.

dialogues.speaker: CABBIE
dialogues.text: You called a cab? Ella answers as she descends the motor home’s steps dragg a bag.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Do you see any other customers waiting around? She shows the bag to John.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here’re all your things. Night, shirt, socks, your damned briefs...  Scene 52 Page 95A.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What’s happening, Ella? Ella doesn't respond. She turns to the taxi driver.  Scene 52 Page 96.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Please help me load my husband and his stupid bag. The intimidated Cabbie gets out and obeys. He carefully p the bag in the trunk. Ella, brusque and furious, opens th back door of the taxi.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to John) Get in, imbecile.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Why are you so mad, Ella?

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Mad? Me? I’m not mad at all. On the contrary - I’m relieved. Happy as a clam! She tells the Cabbie, who is back behind the wheel:

dialogues.speaker: ELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Take us to an old folks’ home. The crummiest you can find.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ella puts the bag and John’s wallet on the reception coun in front of a puzzled Clerk. John looks around, baffled.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: This isn’t where we live.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: No it isn’t. We’re at a place where they keep old fools like you. (to the Clerk) Put him a room, please.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Ella, why are you so irritable? The Clerk, very calmly, as if she’s speaking to a baby, addresses Ella.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Ma’am, we cannot accept new patients without following established guidelines.  Scene 53 Page 97.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Establish them, then.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: You can come tomorrow morning at 9:30 to the intake office. If the gentleman falls within the required parameters he will be put ona waiting list. KEY WEST CAMPSITE —- MORNING 64 The following morning, the Texan is having breakfast with wife. He sees that the Leisure Seeker’s engine is running Perplexed, he goes to knock on the door. Then he opens it

dialogues.speaker: ELLA V/O, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know how painful it must be. But pretty soon you’re going to feel something else. Relief. Relief that you won’t have to watch our bodies and our minds fade away. Relief that the burden we were becoming has been lifted from your shoulders. And you musn’t feel guilty about that...you musn’t. A deeply upset Texan emerges from the Leisure Seeker, cal for help. Other campers flock to the scene, joined by campsite staff. One of them enters the camper to turn off engine, while someone else calls 911.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA V/O, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I loved your father. Very much. I didn’t have much longer, and I couldn’t leave him alone. We were always together. And I hope we’re together somewhere now. Who knows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The funeral’s in their home town cemetery. Will is there, is Jane, with her husband and their children: 21 year-old Rose and 19 year-old Stephen. Many old friends. And Lilli who seems the saddest of all.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA V/O
dialogues.text: This was our last wonderful vacation. We had some beautiful days. It was our happy ending. As they walk away, Jane keeps a close eye on her brother, worried that he will not be able to handle this. Will folds his mother’s letter and puts it in his pocket. He’s read and re-read it many times. He catches his siste eye:

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: How you doing, kiddo? Sad? And he, with a bittersweet smile, shakes his head. He put his arm around her waist and they walk off together.
